column4: anybody know why when i try and telnet to my ubuntu machine it says "connection refused".  just installed ubuntu and haven't messed with any settings
oh... how do i get it to run?
can you connect to localhost from the same pc?
wy not use ssh?
i know... going to use that
how do i connect to localhost?
sit at the same pc you want to telnet to and connect to localhost rather than an IP address
it says "connection refused" when i try and connect to my own ip
then it's not running. I suggest you install openssh-server and use that instead. Its secure
i can do that via synaptic?  what's the exact package name?
openssh-server. or you can run: sudo apt-get install openssh-server   and get it faster
i also see a package just called "ssh" shoul i install that too?
thats a client and is already installed
the box isn't green in synaptic so i don't think it's installed
if you run the command I gave you will get the server
screw synaptic, just run the command I gave
when i set up ubuntu i don't think it ever prompted me for a root password?  is that possible?
yes absolutely, there is no root pass. You use your OWN password in conjunction with sudo and gksudo to get elevated priveledges
no, if you use: ssh servername    it will use your username, not root
or if you want to connect as a different user, use:   ssh username@server
if you are being asked to log in as root then your current user is root and thats not supported in ubuntu
that did it right... many thanks
if you dont use root, you will have fewer issues
